THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Edward C. "Buddy" Cribb, III, Appellant,
				v.
				Dean Spatholt
      and Clark Callahan, in their individual capacities, and Boundary House, Inc., Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Horry County
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4519
Heard January 6, 2009 â€“ Filed March 24,
  2009
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Henrietta U. Golding and Amanda A. Bailey, both of Myrtle Beach,
  for Appellant.
				Arthur E. Justice, Jr., and Reginald W. Belcher, both of Florence,
  for Respondents.
			
		
	

LOCKEMY, J.:Â  Edward C. "Buddy"
  Cribb, III appeals the circuit court's grant of Dean Spatholt, Clark Callahan,
    and Boundary House's Rule 12(b)(2), SCRCP, motion to dismiss for lack of
    personal jurisdiction.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS/PROCEDURAL
  BACKGROUND
Spatholt
  and Callahan own and operate Boundary House (Boundary), a seafood restaurant.Â 
  Boundary is a North Carolina company organized under North Carolina law with its
  principal place of business located at 1045 River Road, Calabash, North Carolina.Â  Spatholt serves as Boundary's president and treasurer, while Callahan
  serves as vice-president and secretary.Â  Both serve on Boundary's board of
  directors.Â  
Prior
  to Boundary's opening, Spatholt and Callahan approached Buddy Cribb to assist
  with the business. According to Buddy's affidavit and complaint, Spatholt and
  Callahan first approached him in December of 2003, while he was working at the
  Carolina Roadhouse in Myrtle Beach, South Carolina.Â  It appears Buddy merely
  spoke with Spatholt and Callahan about Boundary and did not enter into any type
  of contract with them in 2003.Â  Later, Spatholt and Callahan approached Buddy's
  father, Edward, to assist with the planning and operation of Boundary.Â 
  According to Edward, he met with Callahan at the Carolina Roadhouse in Myrtle
  Beach twice in January of 2004 to negotiate and discuss restaurant plans.Â 
  Thereafter, Edward entered into a contract with Spatholt and Callahan to work
  as a consultant for Boundary, and he agreed to help recruit his son, Buddy, as Boundary's
  general manager.Â  
In
  early 2004, Edward contacted Buddy from Myrtle Beach about the general manager
  position at Boundary.Â  Around May 2005, Buddy met with Spatholt and Callahan
  and discussed the potential employment.Â  Shortly thereafter, Spatholt and
  Callahan offered, and Buddy accepted, the general manager position.Â  Buddy
  alleged Callahan promised to employ him for at least ten years.Â  Additionally,
  Callahan promised Buddy the following compensation and benefits:Â  an annual
  salary of $150,000, use of an automobile at Boundary's expense, health
  insurance benefits, a cell phone and monthly plan for Buddy and his wife, two
  days off per week, and two weeks paid vacation.Â  In reliance on this offer,
  Buddy resigned from his position as an operating partner of California Dreaming
  in Augusta, Georgia, and he and his family moved to Myrtle Beach.Â  Buddy commuted
  to and from work while living in Horry County.Â  
On
  September 12, 2006, the Cribbs sued Callahan and Spatholt in their individual
  capacities and Boundary.Â  In his complaint, Buddy maintained Spatholt
  unilaterally terminated him on September 1, 2006, and also sued for breach of
  contract, promissory estoppel, violation of the South Carolina Payment of Wages
  Act, and negligent misrepresentation.Â  Collectively, Boundary, Callahan, and
  Spatholt moved to dismiss both cases for lack of personal jurisdiction,
  pursuant to Rule 12(b)(2), SCRCP.Â  In a preliminary order, the circuit court
  granted the motion to dismiss. Â In a final order, the circuit court dismissed
  the case with prejudice after finding South Carolina lacked specific and
  general jurisdiction over Boundary, as a business, and over Callahan and
  Spatholt, in their individual capacities.Â  
As
  to general jurisdiction the circuit held Boundary, Callahan, and Spatholt "maintained
  no continuous and systematic general business contacts with South Carolina that
  were so substantial and of such a nature to justify allowing [Buddy Cribb] to
  proceed with these lawsuits in this [c]ourt."Â Â  In regards to specific
  jurisdiction, the circuit court found Boundary, Callahan, and Spatholt "did
  not engage in any of the requisite conduct that the long arm statute
  references."Â  Further, the circuit court found subjecting Boundary,
  Callahan, and Spatholt to litigation in South Carolina violated due process
  because 1) the litigation would be unfair and unreasonable to them; 2) South
  Carolina had no viable interest in adjudicating a dispute involving conduct of
  a restaurant operating solely in Brunswick County, North Carolina; and 3) Buddy
  Cribb knew or reasonably should have known that Boundary operated exclusively
  in North Carolina; thus, requiring Buddy Cribb to adjudicate the lawsuit there
  would not be unfair.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court dismissed Buddy Cribb's
  lawsuit with prejudice.Â  This appeal follows.Â  
ISSUE
Did
  the circuit court err in dismissing Buddy Cribb's suit after finding it lacked
  personal jurisdiction over Boundary as a business entity and Callahan and Spatholt
  individually? 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The
  question of personal jurisdiction over a nonresident defendant is one which
  must be resolved upon the facts of each particular case.Â  State v. NV
    Sumatra Tobacco Trading, Co., 379 S.C. 81, 88, 666 S.E.2d 218, 221 (2008). Â The
  circuit court's decision should be affirmed unless unsupported by the evidence
  or influenced by an error of law. Â Cockrell v. Hillerich & Bradsby Co.,
  363 S.C. 485, 491, 611 S.E.2d 505, 508 (2005).Â  "At the pretrial stage,
  the burden of proving personal jurisdiction over a nonresident is met by a
  prima facie showing of jurisdiction either in the complaint or in affidavits."
  Â Id.Â  "When a nonresident defendant attacks the allegations of a
  complaint based on jurisdiction, the court is not confined to the allegations
  of the complaint but may resort to affidavits or other evidence to determine
  jurisdiction."Â  Power Prods. & Servs. Co. v. Kozma, 379 S.C. 423,
  430, 665 S.E.2d 660, 664 (Ct. App. 2008).
PERSONAL JURISDICTION LAW
"The
  concept of jurisdiction refers to the authority of a court over a particular
  person (personal jurisdiction) or the authority of a court to entertain a
  particular action (subject matter jurisdiction), but the concept does not refer
  to the validity of the claim on which an action against a person is based."Â  Boan v. Jacobs, 296 S.C. 419, 421, 373 S.E.2d 697, 698 (Ct. App. 1988).Â 
  In the present case, we are concerned with personal, rather than subject matter
  jurisdiction.Â  Personal jurisdiction is exercised as "general jurisdiction"
  or "specific jurisdiction." Coggeshall v. Reprod. Endocrine Assocs.
    of Charlotte, 376 S.C. 12, 16, 655 S.E.2d 476, 478 (2007).Â  
I.Â 
  General Jurisdiction
Section 36-2-802 of
  the South Carolina Code (2003) governs general jurisdiction and states:Â  "A
  court may exercise personal jurisdiction over a person domiciled in, organized
  under the laws of, doing business, or maintaining his or its principal place of
  business in, this State as to any cause of action."Â  "A court may
  assert general jurisdiction if the defendant has an 'enduring relationship'
  with the forum state." Â Cockrell, 363 S.C. at 495, 611 S.E.2d at
  510.Â  If an individual has an "enduring relationship" with the State,
  he may be sued here even if the cause of action did not arise in South Carolina. See id. ("General jurisdiction attaches even when the
  nonresident defendant's contacts with the forum state are not directly related
  to the cause of action . . . .").Â  To satisfy the "enduring
  relationship" requirement of general jurisdiction, the defendant's
  contacts must be "continuous and systematic" as well as "so
  substantial and of such a nature as to justify suit against the defendant on
  causes of action arising from dealings entirely different from those activities."Â  See id. (citing Int'l Shoe Co. v. Washington, 326 U.S.
  310, 318 (1945)); Coggeshall, 376 S.C. at 17, 655 S.E.2d at 479 (2007) ("An
  enduring relationship is indicated by contacts that are substantial,
  continuous, and systematic.").Â  Furthermore, the defendant's contacts with
  the forum must satisfy the due process clause.Â  Cockrell, 363 S.C. at
  495, 611 S.E.2d at 510.Â  
II.Â 
  Specific Jurisdiction
Courts
  may also have specific jurisdiction over a cause of action arising from a
  defendant's contacts with the state pursuant to the long-arm statute. Â State
    v. NV Sumatra Tobacco Trading, Co., 379 S.C. 81, 88, 666 S.E.2d 218, 222
  (2008).Â  Under the long arm statute, a court may exercise personal jurisdiction
  over an individual acting directly or through an agent for causes of action
  arising from the individual's:

	(1)
  transacting any business in this State;
	(2)
  contracting to supply services or things in the State;
	(3)
  commission of a tortious act in whole or in part in this State;
	(4)
  causing tortious injury or death in this State by an act or omission outside
  this State if he regularly does or solicits business, or engages in any other
  persistent course of conduct, or derives substantial revenue from goods used or
  consumed or services rendered in this State;
	(5)
  having an interest in, using, or possessing real property in this State;
	(6)
  contracting to insure any person, property, or risk located within this State
  at the time of contracting;
	(7)
  entry into a contract to be performed in whole or in part by either party in
  this State; or
	(8)
  production, manufacture, or distribution of goods with the reasonable
  expectation that those goods are to be used or consumed in this State and are
  so used or consumed.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-2-803
  (Supp. 2008).Â  Traditionally, our courts have conducted a two-step analysis to
  determine whether specific jurisdiction is proper by 1) determining if the long
  arm statute applies and 2) determining whether the nonresident's contacts in South Carolina are sufficient to satisfy due process requirements.Â  Power Prods. &
    Servs. Co. v. Kozma, 379 S.C. 423, 431, 665 S.E.2d 660, 664 (Ct. App. 2008).Â 
  However, a more recent trend compresses the analysis into a due process
  assessment only.Â  Id. at 431, 665 S.E.2d at 664-65; see also Cockrell,Â 
  363 S.C. at 491, 611 S.E.2d at 508 ("Because South Carolina treats its
  long-arm statute as coextensive with the due process clause, the sole question
  becomes whether the exercise of personal jurisdiction would violate due
  process.").Â  Â 
Due process
  requires a defendant possess minimum contacts with the forum state such that
  maintenance of suit does not offend traditional notions of fair play and
  substantial justice.Â  Coggeshall, 376 S.C. at 16, 655 S.E.2d at 478.Â  "Further,
  the due process requirement mandates the defendant possess sufficient minimum
  contacts with the forum state such that he could reasonably anticipate being
  haled into court there."Â  Power Prods., 379 S.C. at 431-32, 665
  S.E.2d at 665.
Courts apply a
  two-pronged analysis when determining whether a defendant possesses minimum
  contacts with the forum state such that maintenance of suit does not offend
  traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice.Â  Id. at 432,
  665 S.E.2d at 665.Â  "The court must (1) find that the defendant has the
  requisite minimum contacts with the forum, without which, the court does not
  have the "power" to adjudicate the action and (2) find the exercise
  of jurisdiction is reasonable or fair."Â  Id.Â  To support a finding
  of due process, both prongs must be satisfied.Â  Id.
To
  satisfy the power prong, the court must find the defendant directed his activities
  to residents of South Carolina and that the cause of action arises out of or
  relates to those activities. Â Moosally v. W.W. Norton & Co., 358
  S.C. 320, 331-32, 594 S.E.2d 878, 884 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The Moosally court stated:

	It is
  essential in each case that there be some act by which the defendant
  purposefully avails itself of the privilege of conducting activities within the
  forum state, thus invoking the benefits and protections of its laws. Â The "purposeful
  availment" requirement ensures that a defendant will not be haled into a
  jurisdiction solely as a result of random, fortuitous, or attenuated contacts.
  Whether the constitutional requirement of minimum contacts has been met depends
  on the facts of each case. 

Id. at 332, 594 S.E.2d at 884-85.Â  Finally, under the
  fairness prong, the court must consider the following factors:Â  (1) the
  duration of the defendant's activity in this State; (2) the character and
  circumstances of its acts; (3) the inconvenience to the parties by conferring
  or refusing to confer jurisdiction over the nonresident; and (4) the State's
  interest in exercising jurisdiction.Â  NV Sumatra Tobacco Trading, 379
  S.C. at 91, 666 S.E.2d at 223.
ARGUMENTS AND ANALYSIS
I.  Personal Jurisdiction of Buddy Cribb's Claims
  Against Boundary and Callahan and Spatholt Individually
Buddy Cribb argues
  the circuit court erred in dismissing his suit for lack of personal
  jurisdiction over Boundary as a business entity, and Callahan and Spatholt
  individually.Â  He maintains the long arm statute applies to Boundary, Callahan,
  and Spatholt based on the following activities:Â  (1) transacting any business
  in this State; (2) causing tortious injury or death in this State by an act or
  omission outside this State if he regularly does or solicits business, or
  engages in any other persistent course of conduct, or derives substantial
  revenue from goods used or consumed or services rendered in this State; and (3)
  entry into a contract to be performed in whole or in part by either party in
  this State.[1]Â 
  Moreover, Buddy argues Boundary possessed the requisite minimum contacts to
  satisfy due process.Â  We believe the circuit court did not err in dismissing
  Buddy's case based on Buddy's contract with Boundary and Boundary's presence in
  South Carolina.Â  
A.)Â 
  Due Process Based on Contract
In
  support of Buddy's assertion that Boundary possesses minimum contacts with South Carolina, Buddy argues Boundary directed its activities towards the State by recruiting
  him in South Carolina.Â  Buddy argues Boundary purposefully availed itself to
  the benefits of doing business in South Carolina based on this recruitment.Â 
  Buddy also asserts Boundary purchased numerous food products, supplies, linens,
  and other goods from South Carolina in furtherance of its business activities.Â 
  We find South Carolina lacks personal jurisdiction over Boundary if we only
  examine Buddy's contract.
Our
  courts have held entering into a contract or mere negotiations inside South
  Carolina without more is not enough to establish minimum contacts.Â  Loyd
    & Ring's Wholesale Nursery, Inc. v. Long & Woodley Landscaping &
    Garden Ctr, Inc., 315 S.C. 88, 92, 431 S.E.2d 632, 635 (Ct. App. 1993) (citing Burger King Corp. v. Rudzewicz, 471 U.S. 462, 478-79 (1985)).Â  In Loyd,
  this court stated:Â  "An individual's contract with an out-of-state party
  cannot alone establish sufficient minimum contact's in the other party's home
  forum."Â  Id.Â  Furthermore the court found:Â  "The parties'
  prior negotiations, the consequences of their actions as contemplated by the
  parties, the terms of the contract, and the parties' actual course of dealings
  must be considered in evaluating whether a defendant purposefully established
  minimum contacts within the forum."Â  Id.Â  
This
  court has held South Carolina has jurisdiction over a party who entered into a
  contract that was to be partly performed within the State.Â  Atl. Wholesale
    Co., Inc. v. Solondz, 283 S.C. 36, 320 S.E.2d 720 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  In Solondz,
  a New York resident agreed to purchase silver from Atlantic Wholesale.Â  Id. at 37, 320 S.E.2d at 721.Â  However, when Solondz later refused to pay for the
  silver, Atlantic Wholesale brought suit in South Carolina.Â  Id.Â  Our
  court held South Carolina had jurisdiction over the suit because "the
  evidence presented at the hearing on the motion to dismiss clearly show[ed]
  Solondz entered into a contract that was to be partly performed in South Carolina."Â  Id. at 38, 320 S.E.2d at 722.Â  Moreover this court found
  adjudicating the case within the State would not offend due process even though
  "Solondz ha[d] engaged in little activity in South Carolina . . .
  [because] the length and duration of the activity of the nonresident in this
  State is not deemed important and need only be minimal when the plaintiff lives
  in the forum state and the cause of action arose out of the defendant's
    activities in this State." Id. at 39, 320 S.E.2d at 722 (internal
  citation omitted) (emphasis added).
Buddy
  Cribb knew Boundary was located in Calabash, North Carolina when negotiations
  occurred.Â  In fact, Buddy knew his duties as general manager would include:Â  

	(a)
  creating, training manuals and other employee guidebooks for Boundary; 
	(b)
  designing the layout of the menu and procuring equipment and inventory for the
  kitchen, bar, and dining area of Boundary; 
	(c)
  meeting with consultants and accounting professionals to determine the
  Restaurant's expenses [and] revenues; [and] 
	(d)
  supervising the day-to-day operations of [Boundary], including but not limited
  to, hiring and firing personnel, training new employees, and managing the
  operations of the kitchen, bar, and dining area.

Buddy also indicated he knew
  he would have to purchase supplies from several South Carolina vendors.Â  Based
  on Buddy's own admissions, under the terms of his negotiated contract, he knew
  his work as general manager would occur in North Carolina.Â  Therefore, where he
  would perform his job was within the contemplation of Boundary and Buddy.Â 
  Finally, the parties' actual course of dealings occurred at Boundary's
  principal place of business, in Calabash, North Carolina.Â  Accordingly, South
  Carolina lacks personal jurisdiction over Boundary based solely on Buddy's
  contract.Â  
B.)Â 
  Due Process Based on Presence within the State
Based
  on our courts' recent trend of compressing a personal jurisdiction analysis into
  a due process assessment only, our sole question is whether the exercise of
  personal jurisdiction would violate due process.Â  Cockrell v. Hillerich
    & Bradsby Co.Â  363 S.C. 485, 491, 611 S.E.2d 505, 508 (2005) ("Because
  South Carolina treats its long-arm statute as coextensive with the due
  process clause, the sole question becomes whether the exercise of personal
  jurisdiction would violate due process."); Power Prods. & Servs. Co.
    v. Kozma, 379 S.C. 423, 665 S.E.2d 660 (Ct. App. 2008) (where our court
  assessed only a due process analysis to determine whether specific jurisdiction
  was proper).Â  Accordingly, we must determine whether Boundary possesses minimum
  contacts with South Carolina so as not to offend due process.Â  Under the
  two-pronged analysis, we must determine whether Boundary (1) had the requisite
  minimum contacts with South Carolina, without which, the court does not have
  the "power" to adjudicate the action and (2) find the exercise of
  jurisdiction is reasonable or fair.Â  
Boundary
  had more than random contacts within South Carolina under the power prong.Â  S.
    Plastics Co. v. S. Commerce Bank, 310 S.C. 256, 262, 423 S.E.2d 128, 132
  (1992) ("This 'purposeful availment' requirement ensures that a defendant
  will not be haled into a jurisdiction solely as a result of random, fortuitous,
  or attenuated contacts.").Â  Boundary was present in the state via its
  agents Callahan, Spatholt, and Edward.Â  Boundary directed its activities toward
  South Carolina by soliciting and contracting with Edward and Buddy here
  regarding their respective roles with designing and operating Boundary.Â  In
  fact, Boundary admits it "hired some service providers from Horry County
  to assist with planning the construction of the Restaurant in Calabash, North
  Carolina."Â  
Edward
  Cribb, as an agent of Boundary, maintains he:Â  met with Spatholt and Callahan
  to discuss plans for Boundary while in Myrtle Beach; recruited Buddy as
  Boundary's general manager at Callahan's request from Myrtle Beach; met with
  Callahan and Spatholt several times at architect William R. Halasz's offices in
  Myrtle Beach to discuss and review prospective drawings, design, and layout of
  Boundary; contacted a Myrtle Beach restaurant planner who drafted proposed
  plans for the layout of Boundary's kitchen; met with representatives from
  Jacobi-Lewis Company to discuss the layout of Boundary's kitchen and revised
  and made changes to the layout at the meeting; closed Aspen Grill and
  thereafter Boundary hired former employees from Aspen Grill.Â Â  
Enough
  business was conducted within the state to satisfy the power prong because:Â  1)
  negotiations took place in South Carolina; 2) Edward, as Boundary's agent,
  transacted business here; and 3) Callahan and Spatholt, as Boundary's agents,
  met with Edward's contacts in South Carolina to discuss plans for opening
  Boundary with South Carolina businesses.Â  Based on these contacts, we believe
  Boundary has sufficient minimum contacts with South Carolina such that it would
  expect to be haled into court here.Â  Accordingly, Buddy met the requirements of
  the power prong.
However,
  the fairness prong of the minimum contacts test fails.Â  As explained above,
  courts look at the following four factors in determining whether exercise of
  jurisdiction is reasonable or fair:Â  (1) the duration of the defendant's
  activity in this State; (2) the character and circumstances of its acts; (3)
  the inconvenience to the parties by conferring or refusing to confer
  jurisdiction over the nonresident; and (4) the State's interest in exercising
  jurisdiction.Â  State v. NV Sumatra Tobacco Trading, Co., 379 S.C. 81, 91,
  666 S.E.2d 218, 223 (2008). 
Under
  the first prong, Boundary's activity within the State of negotiating an
  employment contract with Buddy was brief.Â  Second, the character and
  circumstances of the negotiations with Buddy were preliminary discussions
  regarding Buddy's role as general manager.Â  The parties knew Buddy would
  actually perform his duties under the contract at Boundary's principal place of
  business and any other contacts formed within the state are not part of Buddy's
  conflict.Â  Third, as Buddy admits in his appeal, Calabash, North Carolina is
  only two miles outside the South Carolina border.Â  Further, Buddy commuted to North Carolina daily for work, and he currently lives close to the North Carolina border.Â 
  Therefore, it would not significantly inconvenience either party to adjudicate
  the suit in North Carolina.Â  
Finally,
  the State's interest in exercising jurisdiction is small.Â  Our supreme court,
  in addressing this prong, held South Carolina's interest in providing redress
  for its citizens was diminished when "nothing which [was] the subject of
  this litigation ha[d] taken place in South Carolina."Â  Aviation Assocs.
    & Consultants, Inc. v. Jet Time, Inc., 303 S.C. 502, 509, 402 S.E.2d
  177, 181 (1991.Â  Specifically, the Aviation Court stated:Â  "[W]hile
  South Carolina has an interest in providing redress for its citizens, that
  interest is diminished when no business was transacted in this State and any
  contract formed was not to be performed in this State."Â  Id. Â Further,
  the State's interest in exercising jurisdiction further diminishes when public
  policy issues are taken into account.Â  Here, any business relationship Boundary
  maintained within the State is unrelated to the current conflict, and a ruling
  reversing the circuit court could discourage business relationships within
  South Carolina that have nothing to do with the litigation. Â Because the
  fairness prong of the minimum contact analysis fails, adjudication of the suit
  in South Carolina would offend due process.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the circuit
  court's order dismissing Buddy Cribb's suit for lack of personal jurisdiction.
C.)Â 
  Personal Jurisdiction over Callahan and Spatholt individually
For
  reasons similar to the ones stated above, we believe Callahan and Spatholt
  individually possess enough minimum contacts with South Carolina so as not to
  offend due process under the power prong.Â  However, the fairness prong of the
  due process analysis fails for reasons similar to those stated above.Â  The crux
  of our reasoning here is based on Aviation which held South Carolina's
  interest in providing redress for its citizens was diminished when "nothing
  which [was] the subject of this litigation ha[d] taken place in South Carolina."Â 
  303 S.C. at 509, 402 S.E.2d at 181.Â  The circuit court's dismissal of Buddy
  Cribb's suit for lack of personal jurisdiction in regards to Boundary as a
  business entity and Callahan and Spatholt individually is therefore 
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and THOMAS, J.J., concur.


[1] These activities correspond to sections 1, 4, and 7
  of the long arm statute, respectively.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-2-803 (Supp.
  2008).Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Edward C.
      Cribb, Appellant,
				v.
				Dean Spatholt
      and Clark Callahan, in their individual capacities, and Boundary House, Inc., Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Horry County
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4520
Heard January 6, 2009 â€“ Filed March 24,
  2009
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Henrietta U. Golding and Amanda A. Bailey, both of Myrtle Beach,
  for Appellant.
				Arthur E. Justice, Jr. and Reginald W. Belcher, of Florence, for
  Respondents.
			
		
	

LOCKEMY, J.:Â  Edward C. Cribb appeals the circuit
  courtâ€™s grant of Dean Spatholt, Clark Callahan, and Boundary Houseâ€™s Rule 12(b)(2),
  SCRCP, motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction.Â  We reverse.Â  
FACTS/PROCEDURAL
  BACKGROUND
Spatholt
  and Callahan own and operate Boundary House (Boundary), a seafood restaurant.Â 
  Boundary is a North Carolina company organized under North Carolina law with its
  principal place of business located at 1045 River Road, Calabash, North
  Carolina.Â  Spatholt serves as Boundaryâ€™s president and treasurer, while
  Callahan serves as vice-president and secretary.Â  Both serve on Boundaryâ€™s
  board of directors.Â  
Prior
  to Boundaryâ€™s opening, Spatholt and Callahan approached Edward and his son, Buddy
  Cribb, to assist with the business.Â  According to Buddyâ€™s affidavit and
  complaint, Spatholt and Callahan first approached him in December of 2003,
  while he was working at the Carolina Roadhouse in Myrtle Beach, South
  Carolina.Â  It appears Buddy merely spoke with Spatholt and Callahan about Boundary
  and did not enter into any type of contract with them in 2003.Â  Later, Spatholt
  and Callahan approached Edward to assist with the planning and operation of Boundary.Â 
  According to Edward, he met with Callahan at the Carolina Roadhouse in Myrtle
  Beach twice in January of 2004 to negotiate and discuss restaurant plans.Â 
  Thereafter, Edward entered into a contract with Spatholt and Callahan to work
  as a consultant for Boundary.Â  Under the terms of the contract, Spatholt and
  Callahan agreed to pay Edward $35,000 until Boundary opened and thereafter 5% of
  Boundaryâ€™s gross pre-tax revenues.Â  Additionally, Edward agreed to help recruit
  his son, Buddy, as Boundaryâ€™s general manager.Â  
In
  early 2004, Edward contacted Buddy from Myrtle Beach about the general manager
  position at Boundary.Â  Around May 2005, Buddy met with Spatholt and Callahan
  and discussed the potential employment.Â  Shortly thereafter, Spatholt and
  Callahan offered, and Buddy accepted, the general manager position.Â  
On
  September 12, 2006, Edward Cribb sued Callahan and Spatholt in their individual
  capacities and Boundary.Â  In his complaint, Edward maintained Spatholt
  unilaterally terminated him on August 14, 2006, and alleged the following
  causes of action:Â  breach of contract, promissory estoppel, violation of the
  South Carolina Payment of Wages Act, and negligent misrepresentation.Â Â Â  Buddy
  Cribb also filed suit.Â  Collectively, Boundary, Callahan, and Spatholt moved to
  dismiss both cases for lack of personal jurisdiction, pursuant to Rule
  12(b)(2), SCRCP.Â  In a preliminary order, the circuit court granted the motion
  to dismiss.Â  In a final order, the circuit court dismissed the case with
  prejudice after finding South Carolina lacked specific and general jurisdiction
  over Boundary, as a business, and over Callahan and Spatholt, in their
  individual capacities.Â  
As
  to general jurisdiction the circuit court held Boundary, Callahan, and Spatholt
  â€œmaintained no continuous and systematic general business contacts with South
  Carolina that were so substantial and of such a nature to justify allowing [Edward]
  to proceed with these lawsuits in this [c]ourt.â€Â  In regards to specific
  jurisdiction, the circuit court found Boundary, Callahan, and Spatholt â€œdid not
  engage in any of the requisite conduct that the long arm statute references.â€Â 
  Further, the circuit court found subjecting Boundary, Callahan, and Spatholt to
  litigation in South Carolina violated due process because 1) the litigation
  would be unfair and unreasonable to them; 2) South Carolina had no viable
  interest in adjudicating a dispute involving conduct of a restaurant operating
  solely in Brunswick County, North Carolina; and 3) Edward Cribb knew or
  reasonably should have known that Boundary operated exclusively in North
  Carolina; thus, requiring Edward to adjudicate the lawsuit there would not be
  unfair.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court dismissed Edward Cribbâ€™s lawsuit with
  prejudice.Â  This appeal follows.Â  
ISSUE
Did
  the circuit court err in dismissing Edward Cribbâ€™s case after finding it lacked
  personal jurisdiction over Boundary as a business entity and Callahan and
  Spatholt individually?
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The
  question of personal jurisdiction over a nonresident defendant is one which
  must be resolved upon the facts of each particular case.Â  State v. NV
    Sumatra Tobacco Trading, Co., 379 S.C. 81, 88, 666 S.E.2d 218, 221 (2008). Â The
  circuit courtâ€™s decision should be affirmed unless unsupported by the evidence
  or influenced by an error of law. Â Cockrell v. Hillerich & Bradsby Co.,
  363 S.C. 485, 491, 611 S.E.2d 505, 508 (2005).Â  "At the pretrial stage,
  the burden of proving personal jurisdiction over a nonresident is met by a
  prima facie showing of jurisdiction either in the complaint or in affidavits."
  Â Id.Â  "When a nonresident defendant attacks the allegations of a
  complaint based on jurisdiction, the court is not confined to the allegations
  of the complaint but may resort to affidavits or other evidence to determine
  jurisdiction."Â  Power Prods. & Servs. Co. v. Kozma, 379 S.C. 423,
  430, 665 S.E.2d 660, 664 (Ct. App. 2008).
PERSONAL JURISDICTION LAW
â€œThe
  concept of jurisdiction refers to the authority of a court over a particular
  person (personal jurisdiction) or the authority of a court to entertain a
  particular action (subject matter jurisdiction), but the concept does not refer
  to the validity of the claim on which an action against a person is based.â€Â  Boan
    v. Jacobs, 296 S.C. 419, 421, 373 S.E.2d 697, 698 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  In the
  present case, we are concerned with personal, rather than subject matter
  jurisdiction.Â  Personal jurisdiction is exercised as â€œgeneral jurisdictionâ€ or
  â€œspecific jurisdiction.â€ Coggeshall v. Reprod. Endocrine Assocs. of
    Charlotte, 376 S.C. 12, 16, 655 S.E.2d 476, 478 (2007).Â  
I.Â 
  General Jurisdiction
Section 36-2-802 of
  the South Carolina Code (2003) governs general jurisdiction and states:Â  â€œA
  court may exercise personal jurisdiction over a person domiciled in, organized
  under the laws of, doing business, or maintaining his or its principal place of
  business in, this State as to any cause of action.â€Â  A court may assert general
  jurisdiction if the defendant has an â€œenduring relationshipâ€ with the forum
  state. Â Cockrell v. Hillerich & Bradsby Co., 363 S.C. 485, 495, 611
  S.E.2d 505, 510 (2005).Â  If an individual has an â€œenduring relationshipâ€ with
  the State, he may be sued here even if the cause of action did not arise in South Carolina. Â See id. (â€œGeneral jurisdiction attaches even when the
  nonresident defendantâ€™s contacts with the forum state are not directly related
  to the cause of action . . . .â€).Â  To satisfy the â€œenduring relationshipâ€
  requirement of general jurisdiction, the defendantâ€™s contacts must be â€œcontinuous
  and systematicâ€ as well as â€œso substantial and of such a nature as to justify
  suit against the defendant on causes of action arising from dealings entirely
  different from those activities.â€Â  See id. (citing Int'l Shoe
    Co. v. Washington, 326 U.S. 310, 318 (1945)); Coggeshall, 376 S.C. at
  17, 655 S.E.2d at 479 (â€œAn enduring relationship is indicated by contacts that
  are substantial, continuous, and systematic.â€).Â  Furthermore, the defendantâ€™s
  contacts with the forum must satisfy the due process clause.Â  Cockrell,
  363 S.C. at 495, 611 S.E.2d at 510.
II.
  Â Specific Jurisdiction
Courts
  may also have specific jurisdiction over a cause of action arising from a
  defendantâ€™s contacts with the state pursuant to the long-arm statute. Â State
    v. NV Sumatra Tobacco Trading, Co., 379 S.C. 81, 88, 666 S.E.2d 218, 222 (2008).Â 
  Under the long arm statute, a court may exercise personal jurisdiction over an
  individual acting directly or through an agent for causes of action arising
  from the individualâ€™s:

	(1)
  transacting any business in this State;
	(2)
  contracting to supply services or things in the State;
	(3)
  commission of a tortious act in whole or in part in this State;
	(4)
  causing tortious injury or death in this State by an act or omission outside
  this State if he regularly does or solicits business, or engages in any other
  persistent course of conduct, or derives substantial revenue from goods used or
  consumed or services rendered in this State;
	(5)
  having an interest in, using, or possessing real property in this State;
	(6)
  contracting to insure any person, property, or risk located within this State
  at the time of contracting;
	(7)
  entry into a contract to be performed in whole or in part by either party in
  this State; or
	(8)
  production, manufacture, or distribution of goods with the reasonable
  expectation that those goods are to be used or consumed in this State and are
  so used or consumed.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-2-803
  (Supp. 2008).Â  Traditionally, our courts have conducted a two-step analysis to
  determine whether specific jurisdiction is proper by 1) determining if the long
  arm statute applies and 2) determining whether the nonresidentâ€™s contacts in South Carolina are sufficient to satisfy due process requirements.Â  Power Prods. &
    Servs. Co. v. Kozma, 379 S.C. 423, 431, 665 S.E.2d 660, 664 (Ct. App. 2008).Â 
  However, a more recent trend compresses the analysis into a due process
  assessment only.Â  Id. at 431, 665 S.E.2d at 664-65; see also Cockrell,Â 
  363 S.C. at 491, 611 S.E.2d at 508 (â€œBecause South Carolina treats its long-arm
  statute as coextensive with the due process clause, the sole question becomes
  whether the exercise of personal jurisdiction would violate due process.â€).Â  Â 
Due process
  requires a defendant possess minimum contacts with the forum state such that
  maintenance of suit does not offend traditional notions of fair play and
  substantial justice.Â  Coggeshall, 376 S.C. at 16, 655 S.E.2d at 478.Â  â€œFurther,
  the due process requirement mandates the defendant possess sufficient minimum
  contacts with the forum state such that he could reasonably anticipate being haled
  into court there.â€Â  Power Prods., 379 S.C. at 431-32, 665 S.E.2d at 665.
Courts apply a
  two-pronged analysis when determining whether a defendant possesses minimum
  contacts with the forum state such that maintenance of suit does not offend
  traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice.Â  Id. at 432,
  665 S.E.2d at 665.Â  â€œThe court must (1) find that the defendant has the
  requisite minimum contacts with the forum, without which, the court does not
  have the 'power' to adjudicate the action and (2) find the exercise of
  jurisdiction is reasonable or fair.â€Â  Id.Â  To support a finding of due
  process, both prongs must be satisfied.Â  Id.
To
  satisfy the power prong, the court must find the defendant directed his activities
  to residents of South Carolina and that the cause of action arises out of or
  relates to those activities. Â Moosally v. W.W. Norton & Co., Inc.,
  358 S.C. 320, 331-32, 594 S.E.2d 878, 884 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The Moosally court stated:

	It is
  essential in each case that there be some act by which the defendant
  purposefully avails itself of the privilege of conducting activities within the
  forum state, thus invoking the benefits and protections of its laws. Â The
  â€œpurposeful availmentâ€ requirement ensures that a defendant will not be haled into
  a jurisdiction solely as a result of random, fortuitous, or attenuated
  contacts. Whether the constitutional requirement of minimum contacts has been
  met depends on the facts of each case. 

358 S.C. at 332, 594 S.E.2d at
  884-85 (internal citations omitted).Â  Finally, under the fairness prong, the
  court must consider the following factors:Â  (1) the duration of the defendantâ€™s
  activity in this State; (2) the character and circumstances of its acts; (3)
  the inconvenience to the parties; and (4) the Stateâ€™s interest in exercising
  jurisdiction.Â  NV Sumatra Tobacco Trading, Co., 379 S.C. at 91, 666
  S.E.2d at 223.
ARGUMENTS AND ANALYSIS
I.  Personal
  Jurisdiction of Edward Cribbâ€™s Claims Against Boundary, and Callahan and
  Spatholt individually
Edward Cribb argues the circuit court erred in
  dismissing his suit for lack of personal jurisdiction over Boundary as a
  business entity, and Callahan and Spatholt individually.Â  He maintains the long
  arm statute applies to Boundary, Callahan, and Spatholt based on the following
  activities:Â  (1) transacting any business in this State; (2) causing tortious
  injury or death in this State by an act or omission outside this State if he
  regularly does or solicits business, or engages in any other persistent course
  of conduct, or derives substantial revenue from goods used or consumed or
  services rendered in this State; and (3) entry into a contract to be performed
  in whole or in part by either party in this State.[1]Â 
  Moreover, Edward argues Boundary House possessed the requisite minimum contacts
  to satisfy due process.Â  Upon
    examination of Edward Cribbâ€™s contract with Boundary and Boundaryâ€™s presence in
    the state, we believe Edward met his burden at this stage in the proceeding to
    defeat a 12(b)(2) motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction over Boundary,
    Callahan, and Spatholt.Â  
A.Â  Boundary as
  a Business Entity
Based
  on our courtsâ€™ recent trend of compressing a personal jurisdiction analysis into
  a due process assessment only, our sole question is whether the exercise of
  personal jurisdiction would violate due process.Â  Cockrell v. Hillerich
    & Bradsby Co.Â  363 S.C. 485, 491, 611 S.E.2d 505, 508 (2005) (â€œBecause South Carolina treats its long-arm statute as coextensive with the due process clause, the
  sole question becomes whether the exercise of personal jurisdiction would
  violate due process.â€); Power Prods., 379 S.C. 423, 665 S.E.2d 660
  (where our court assessed only a due process analysis to determine whether
  specific jurisdiction was proper).Â  Accordingly, we must determine whether
  Boundary possesses minimum contacts with South Carolina so as not to offend due
  process.Â  Under the two-pronged analysis, we must determine whether Boundary (1)
  had the requisite minimum contacts with South Carolina, without which, the court
  does not have the â€œpowerâ€ to adjudicate the action, and (2) find the exercise
  of jurisdiction is reasonable or fair.Â  
In
  support of Edwardâ€™s assertion that Boundary possesses minimum contacts with South Carolina, he argues in execution of his contract with Boundary he was to provide
  planning and operation services.Â  Edward maintains Boundary directed its
  activities toward South Carolina by soliciting and contracting with him to
  assist with designing and operating Boundary.Â  In his affidavit Edward specifically
  maintains he:Â  met with Spatholt and Callahan to discuss plans for Boundary
  while in Myrtle Beach; recruited Buddy as Boundaryâ€™s general manager at
  Callahanâ€™s request from Myrtle Beach; met with Callahan and Spatholt several
  times at architect William R. Halaszâ€™s offices in Myrtle Beach to discuss and
  review prospective drawings, design, and layout of Boundary; contacted a Myrtle
  Beach restaurant planner who drafted proposed plans for the layout of
  Boundaryâ€™s kitchen; met with representatives from Jacobi-Lewis Company to
  discuss the layout of Boundaryâ€™s kitchen and revised and made changes to the
  layout at the meeting; closed Aspen Grill and thereafter Boundary hired former
  employees from Aspen Grill.Â  As such, Edward contends Boundary purposefully
  availed itself of the benefits of doing business in South Carolina so that it
  could reasonably anticipate being haled into court here.Â  
Our
  courts have held entering into a contract or mere negotiations inside South Carolina without more is not enough to establish minimum contacts.Â  Loyd &
    Ringâ€™s Wholesale Nursery, Inc. v. Long & Woodley Landscaping & Garden Ctr,
    Inc., 315 S.C. 88, 92, 431 S.E.2d 632, 635 (Ct. App. 1993) (citing Burger
      King Corp. v. Rudzewicz, 471 U.S. 462, 478-79 (1985)).Â  In Loyd,
  this court stated:Â  â€œAn individualâ€™s contract with an out-of-state party cannot
  alone establish sufficient minimum contactâ€™s in the other partyâ€™s home forum.â€Â  Id.Â  Furthermore the court found:Â  â€œThe partiesâ€™ prior negotiations,
  the consequences of their actions as contemplated by the parties, the terms of
  the contract, and the partiesâ€™ actual course of dealings must be considered in
  evaluating whether a defendant purposefully established minimum contacts within
  the forum.â€Â  Id.Â  
Though
  Edward knew Callahan and Spatholt were planning on opening Boundary in
  Calabash, North Carolina, in performing his duties under his contract, Edward
  met with contacts in Myrtle Beach, South Carolina.Â  In fact, Boundary admits it
  â€œhired some service providers from Horry County to assist with planning the
  construction of the Restaurant in Calabash, North Carolina.Â  Therefore, it
  appears Boundary, when forming its contract with Edward, contemplated Edward
  would use his Myrtle Beach contacts, including recruiting his son Buddy, to perform
  his duties of planning and designing Boundary.Â  Therefore, because part of
  Edwardâ€™s contract was to be performed in South Carolina, more than â€œmere
  negotiationsâ€ took place here.Â  
This
  court has held South Carolina has jurisdiction over a party who entered into a
  contract that was to be partly performed within the State.Â  Atl. Wholesale
    Co. v. Solondz, 283 S.C. 36, 37, 320 S.E.2d 720, 721 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  In Solondz,
  a New York resident, agreed to purchase silver from Atlantic Wholesale.Â  Id.Â 
  However, when Solondz later refused to pay for the silver, Atlantic Wholesale
  brought suit in South Carolina.Â  Id.Â  Our court held South Carolina had
  jurisdiction over the suit because â€œthe evidence presented at the hearing on
  the motion to dismiss clearly show[ed] Solondz entered into a contract that was
  to be partly performed in South Carolina.â€Â  Id. at 38, 320 S.E.2d at 722.Â 
  Moreover this court found adjudicating the case within the State would not
  offend due process even though â€œSolondz ha[d] engaged in little activity in
  South Carolina . . . [because] the length and duration of the activity of the
  nonresident in this State is not deemed important and need only be minimal when
  the plaintiff lives in the forum state and the cause of action arose out of
    the defendantâ€™s activities in this State.â€ Id. at 39, 320 S.E.2d at
  722 (internal citation omitted) (emphasis added).
We
  believe personal jurisdiction over Boundary is proper at this stage in the
  proceeding.Â  Boundary negotiated Edwardâ€™s contract in South Carolina, and it
  was within its contemplation that Edward would perform his part of the contract
  here.Â  In fact, Boundary admitted hiring service providers from Horry County to
  assist with planning the construction of the restaurant in Calabash, North
  Carolina.Â  Because the restaurant was not yet in existence at the time the
  contract was entered into, one would logically expect planning to occur at the
  most convenient location for the parties.Â  Therefore, because part of Edwardâ€™s
  contract was to be performed within South Carolina and because Edwardâ€™s cause
  of action arose from a breach of that contract, we believe Boundary has
  sufficient minimum contacts with South Carolina such that it would expect to be
  haled into court here.Â  Accordingly, we find Edward met his pretrial prima
  facie burden of demonstrating personal jurisdiction over Boundary in his
  complaint and affidavits. Â Cockrell v. Hillerich & Bradsby Co., 363
  S.C. 485, 491, 611 S.E.2d 505, 508 (2005).Â  Therefore, Edward met the
  requirements of the power prong.
Lastly,
  we believe the fairness prong of the minimum contacts test is met as well.Â  To
  reiterate, courts look at the following four factors in determining whether exercise
  of jurisdiction is reasonable or fair:Â  (1) the duration of the defendantâ€™s activity
  in this State; (2) the character and circumstances of its acts; (3) the
  inconvenience to the parties; and (4) the Stateâ€™s interest in exercising
  jurisdiction.Â  State v. NV Sumatra Tobacco Trading, Co., 379 S.C. 81, 91,
  666 S.E.2d 218, 223 (2008).
Under
  the first prong, Boundaryâ€™s activity within the State was continuous.Â Â  Edward
  maintains Callahan and Spatholt, as agents of Boundary, came to Myrtle Beach on several occasions to meet and discuss plans for opening Boundary with South Carolina businesses.Â  Further, Edward, on behalf of Boundary, met with several Myrtle
  Beach contacts in performing his part of the contract.Â  Therefore, the duration
  of Edwardâ€™s activity in South Carolina was also continuous.Â  Second, the
  character and circumstances of the negotiations and meetings appear essential
  to Edward fulfilling his part of the contract.Â  It appears several businesses
  within South Carolina were contacted and potentially hired to perform several
  tasks in starting up Boundary.Â  Third, it would not significantly inconvenience
  either party to adjudicate the suit in South Carolina given Boundaryâ€™s
  proximity.Â  
Finally,
  South Carolina has an interest in providing redress for its citizens.Â  Burger
    King Corp. v. Rudzewicz, 471 U.S. 462, 473 (1985) (â€œA State generally has a
  â€˜manifest interestâ€™ in providing its residents with a convenient forum for
  redressing injuries inflicted by out-of-state actors.â€); Springmasters, Inc.
    v. D & M Mfg., 303 S.C. 528, 533, 402 S.E.2d 192, 195 (Ct. App. 1991)
  (â€œSouth Carolina has a legitimate interest in providing its citizens a forum to
  resolve claims for breach of contract.â€).Â  Further, enough business was
  conducted within the state to warrant adjudication of the suit here.Â  Contra Aviation Assocs. & Consultants, Inc. v. Jet Time, Inc., 303 S.C. 502,
  509, 402 S.E.2d 177, 181 (1991) (â€œ[W]hile South Carolina has an interest in
  providing redress for its citizens, that interest is diminished when no
  business was transacted in this State and any contract formed was not to be
  performed in this State.â€).Â  Because both prongs of the minimum contact
  analysis are met, adjudication of Edwardâ€™s suit against Boundary in South Carolina would not offend due process.Â  
B.Â 
  Callahan and Spatholt Individually
For
  reasons similar to the ones stated above, we believe Callahan and Spatholt
  individually possess enough minimum contacts with South Carolina so as not to
  offend due process.Â  These contacts include the following:Â  Callahanâ€™s 2003
  meeting with Buddy Cribb at the Carolina Roadhouse in Myrtle Beach regarding
  Buddyâ€™s interest in helping start a restaurant; Callahan and Spatholtâ€™s two
  2004 meetings with Edward Cribb at the Carolina Roadhouse in Myrtle Beach to
  discuss his interest in starting a new restaurant; and Callahanâ€™s meeting at
  Architect William R. Halaszâ€™s office in Myrtle Beach.Â  Furthermore, Boundary
  filed its Articles of Incorporation on June 23, 2004, and according to Edwardâ€™s
  complaint, Boundary opened for business on November 15, 2005.Â  Therefore, given
  Boundary was not yet in existence when Edward first began acting as a
  consultant, he was acting on Callahan and Spatholtâ€™s behalf rather than on
  Boundaryâ€™s behalf in performing part of his contract.Â  See ML-Lee
    Acquisition Fund, L.P. v. Deloitte & Touche, 327 S.C. 238, 242, 489 S.E.2d
  470, 472 (1997) (â€œ[A]uthorized acts of an agent are the acts of the principal.â€).
  Â Based on Callahan and Spatholtâ€™s contacts, the power prong of the minimum
  contacts analysis is met.Â  
Moreover,
  the fairness prong is also satisfied.Â  Callahan and Spatholt admit to hiring South Carolina businesses and meeting with them in Myrtle Beach.Â  Second, the character and
  circumstances of their negotiations and meetings here appear essential to
  Boundaryâ€™s successful opening.Â  Third, it would not significantly inconvenience
  either party to adjudicate the suit in South Carolina given Boundaryâ€™s
  proximity.Â  Moreover, given our decision regarding personal jurisdiction over Boundary,
  Callahan and Spatholt will likely be in South Carolina on Boundaryâ€™s behalf to
  defend Edwardâ€™s suit.Â  Finally, South Carolina has an interest in providing
  redress for its citizens and enough business was conducted within the state to
  warrant adjudication of the suit here.Â  The circuit court's dismissal of
  Edwardâ€™s suit for lack of personal jurisdiction in regards to Boundary as a
  business entity and Callahan and Spatholt individually is therefore 
REVERSED.
HUFF and THOMAS, J.J., concur.


[1] These activities correspond to sections 1, 4, and 7
  of the long arm statute, respectively.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-2-803 (Supp.
  2008).Â

title: Doe v. Richland County School District Two
description: The Richland County School District Two Board of Trustees (Board) expelled Jane Doe from high school for committing a sexual offense.  The circuit court reversed, finding the Board's decision was not supported by substantial evidence and violated her due process rights.  Richland County School District Two (District) appeals.  We affirm.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Jane Doe, a
          high school student in Richland County School District Two, and her parent,
          Mary Doe, Respondents,
        v.
        Richland County
          School District Two, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â J. Michelle Childs, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4521
  Heard January 8, 2009 â€“ Filed March 25,
2009Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Kenneth L. Childs, Vernie L. Williams, and Jasmine S. Rogers, all of
          Columbia, for Appellant.
        Kimaka Nichols-Graham and Thomas L. Bruce, both of Greenville, for Respondents.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  The Richland County School District Two Board of Trustees
  (Board) expelled Jane Doe from high school for committing a sexual offense.Â 
  The circuit court reversed, finding the Board's decision was not supported by
  substantial evidence and violated her due process rights.Â  Richland County
  School District Two (District) appeals.Â  We affirm. Â 
FACTS
Jane Doe, a
  fourteen-year-old high-school student, began the school year enrolled in the
  District's alternative school at Blythewood Academy (Academy).Â  In August, the
  Academy suspended Doe for two days after she engaged in a verbal altercation
  with another student.Â  Less than a month later, a video camera captured Doe
  following a male student into the boys' restroom.Â  According to Doe, she
  entered the boys' restroom to retrieve a comb the student had taken from her.Â 
  Doe remained in the boys' restroom for about a minute until another male
  student entered the restroom; then, Doe exited the restroom.Â  
Following
  this incident, the Academy suspended Doe for ten days and recommended expulsion
  for the remainder of the year.Â  According to the Academy, Doe committed a sexual
  offense when she entered the boys' restroom with another male student. [1]Â 
  In a letter to Doe, the District notified her of the Academy's recommendation,
  the date of the upcoming evidentiary hearing, and her procedural rights.Â  Prior
  to the hearing, the District recorded over the videotape before Doe was allowed
  to view it.Â  The school administrator and the hearing officer watched the tape
  prior to its destruction and reported only observing Doe enter the boys'
  restroom following a male student.Â  The District did not present any additional
  evidence suggesting Doe committed a sexual offense.Â  Nonetheless, the hearing
  officer found Doe committed a sexual offense and expelled her for the remainder
  of the year. 
Doe timely appealed
  the hearing officer's decision to the Board.Â  The Board, however, upheld the
  hearing officer's decision.Â  Doe appealed the Board's decision to the circuit
  court pursuant to section 59-63-240 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2008).Â 
  The circuit court reversed, finding substantial evidence did not support the
  Board's decision to expel Doe for committing a sexual offense.Â  In addition,
  the court found Doe's due process rights were violated. This appeal followed. Â Â Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A school board's
  decision to expel a student from school "may be appealed to the proper
  court."Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 59-63-240 (Supp. 2008); see Davis v.
    Sch. Dist. of Greenville County, 374 S.C. 39, 44, 647 S.E.2d 219, 222
  (2007) (stating the expulsion provision in the statute, unlike the suspension
  provision, expressly grants the student a right to appeal to the proper
  court).Â  Judicial review of the school board's decision is limited to
  ascertaining whether the board's decision is supported by substantial
  evidence.Â  Laws v. Richland County Sch. Dist. No. 1, 270 S.C. 492, 495,
  243 S.E.2d 192, 193 (1978).Â  However, this court
  cannot substitute its judgment for that of the educational authorities.Â  Id.Â Â  
Â LAW/ANALYSIS
According to the
  District, Doe's voluntary act of entering the boys' restroom with a male
  student amounted to a sexual offense.Â  Thus, the District asserts, given this
  incident and Doe's prior disciplinary history, substantial evidence supports
  the Board's decision to expel her from school.Â  The District complains the
  circuit court improperly substituted its judgment for that of school
  authorities in reversing the Board's decision.Â  We disagree. Â Â Â 
"Substantial
  evidence is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow
  reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the Board reached or must have
  reached in order to justify its action."Â  Kizer v. Dorchester County
    Vocational Educ. Bd. of Trs., 287 S.C. 545, 548, 340 S.E.2d 144, 146 (1986).Â  Â Â 
Doe's
  prior acts of disruptive activity while a student at the District have no
  bearing on the analysis of the question before us.Â  The District chose not to
  expel Doe for any of her prior transgressions and only expelled her for
  committing a sexual offense in violation of Level
  III Item 5 of the District's Discipline Code.Â  Thus, the narrow question before
  us is whether the Board's decision to uphold the expulsion of Doe for
  committing a sexual offense is supported by substantial evidence.Â  
The
  only evidence Doe committed a sexual offense was her voluntary entry into the
  boys' restroom for approximately one minute in pursuit of a male student.Â  The
  school administrator and the hearing officer, the only individuals who viewed
  the videotape, reported observing no more than this.Â  The record does not
  contain any evidence that Doe and the male student engaged in any sort of
  sexual activity or planned to do so.Â  Furthermore, there was no statement from
  the male student or any other student that indicated anything sexual occurred.Â 
  On these facts, we believe substantial evidence does not support the Board's
  decision to expel Doe.Â  
Accordingly,
  the decision of the circuit court is thereforeÂ Â  
AFFIRMED.
SHORT, J., and
  KONDUROS, J., concur.


[1] "Sexual offense" is not defined by the
  Districtâ€™s Discipline Code.Â  However, Level III Item 5 of the Districtâ€™s
Discipline Code, JICDA-R, makes sexual offenses punishable by expulsion.Â

title: State v. Bryant
description: Bryant appeals his convictions for criminal sexual conduct with a minor and lewd acts.  He argues the application of section 17-23-175 of the South Carolina Code to admit videotaped interviews of minor victims was error in light of  language in the statute's savings clause and constituted an ex post facto violation.  We affirm.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Herbert Bryant, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â Paul M. Burch, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4522Â  
  Heard February 3, 2009 â€“ Filed March 25,
2009

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
          General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant
          Attorney General William M. Blitch, Jr., all of Columbia; and Solicitor John
          Gregory Hembree, of Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  

KONDUROS,
  J.:Â  Bryant appeals his convictions
  for three counts of first degree criminal sexual conduct (CSC) with a minor and
  three counts of committing a lewd act on a minor.Â  He contends section
  17-23-175 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2008), which provides for the
  admission of videotaped interviews of child sexual abuse victims under certain
  circumstances, was applied in contradiction to the savings clause accompanying
  enactment of the legislation.Â  Bryant further argues the application of the
  statute violated the ex post facto clauses of the state and federal
  constitutions.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Bryant was tried and convicted of three counts of
  first degree CSC with a minor and three counts of committing a lewd act on a
  minor for molesting three neighbor children.Â  He was sentenced to thirty years'
  imprisonment for each CSC charge and fifteen years for each lewd act charge,
  all to run concurrently.Â  
After
  allegations by the three minor victims, their mother contacted police, and the
  victims were interviewed by a forensic interviewer.Â  At trial, the victims, two
  females and one male, testified Bryant had taken inappropriate pictures of the
  female victims and made the children watch "nasty" videos with him.Â 
  The victims testified Bryant made the male victim and one female victim perform
  oral sex on him at least once.Â  The State sought to introduce the videotapes of
  the victims' forensic interviews into evidence pursuant to section 17-23-175 of
  the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2008).Â  Bryant objected arguing the application
  of the statute would violate the ex post facto clause, and the statute specifically
  did not apply to pending cases pursuant to the savings clause accompanying the
  proposed statute.Â  The trial court allowed the admission of the videotaped
  interviews, concluding section 17-23-175 constituted an addition to the statutory
  scheme and did not amend or repeal the statute as contemplated by the savings
  clause.Â  The trial court further concluded applying section 17-23-175 did not
  constitute an ex post facto violation because it deals with evidentiary
  or procedural issues and not the substantive rights of the defendant.Â  The jury
  convicted Bryant and this appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Savings Clause 
Bryant
  contends the savings clause prohibited the admission of the videotaped
  interviews in his trial, because the savings clause prohibited any repeal or
  amendment from taking effect in pending cases.Â  We disagree.
Section
  17-23-175(A) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2008) allows the admission of
  out-of-court statements by child sexual abuse victims when the following conditions
  are met: 

  (1) the
    statement was given in response to questioning conducted during an
    investigative interview of the child;
  (2)Â Â Â Â  an
    audio and visual recording of the statement is preserved on film, videotape, or
    other electronic means . . . ;
  (3)Â Â Â Â  the
    child testifies at the proceeding and is subject to cross-examination on the
    elements of the offense and the making of the out-of-court statement; and 
  (4)Â Â Â Â  the
    court finds, in a hearing conducted outside the presence of the jury, that the
    totality of the circumstances surrounding the making of the statement provides
    particularized guarantees of the trustworthiness.

The
  savings clause accompanying the enactment of section 17-23-175 provides:

  The repeal or amendment by this act of any law,
    whether temporary or permanent or civil or criminal, does
    not affect pending actions, rights, duties, or liabilities founded thereon, or
    alter, discharge, release, or extinguish any penalty, forfeiture, or liability
    incurred under the repealed or amended law, unless the repealed or amended
    provision shall so expressly provide. 

2006 S.C. Act No. 346  Â§ 7 (the Act) (emphasis added).
Generally,
  a savings clause is intended to be "a restriction in a repealing act,
  which is intended to save rights, pending proceedings, penalties, etc., from
  the annihilation which would result from an unrestricted appeal."Â  Pierce
    v. State, 338 S.C. 139, 146 n.3, 526 S.E.2d 222, 225 n.3 (2000) (quoting Black's
      Law Dictionary 1343 (6th ed. 1990)).

  The longstanding
    common law view is that a "continued prosecution necessarily depend[s]
    upon the continued life of the statute which the prosecution seeks to apply. In
    case a statute is repealed or rendered inoperative, no further proceedings can
    be had to enforce it in pending prosecutions unless competent authority has
    kept the statute alive for that purpose. . . . Prosecution for crimes is but an
    application or enforcement of the law, and if
    the prosecution continues the law must continue to vivify it."

Id. at 145-46, 526 S.E.2d at 225 (quoting U.S. v.
  Chambers, 291 U.S. 217, 223, 226 (1934)) (omission by court).
The
  Act did several things in addition to providing a mechanism for admitting
  out-of-court statements by a child victim of sexual abuse via section 17-23-175.Â 
  The Act also revised the criminal penalties for criminal sexual conduct with a
  minor, including adding the death penalty for certain repeat offenders.Â  It
  also changed some of the procedures and punishment regarding electronic
  monitoring of offenders.Â  
We
  do not believe section 17-23-175 repealed or amended any previously existing
  law as contemplated by the savings clause.Â  Instead, section 17-23-175 was an
  addition to the statutory scheme that deals with the prosecution and punishment
  of sexual offenders.Â  Therefore, we agree with the trial court that the savings
  clause did not prohibit the application of section 17-23-175 in Bryant's case.
II. Ex Post Facto Violation
Bryant also contends the application of section
  17-23-175 constitutes an ex post facto violation making the admission of
  the videotaped interviews error.Â  We disagree.Â  
The
  purpose of an ex post facto clause is to prevent lawmakers from passing
  "arbitrary or vindictive legislation." Â Miller v. Florida, 482
  U.S. 423, 429 (1987) (citations omitted).Â  An ex post facto clause also
  ensures that legislative enactments "give fair warning of their effect and
  permit individuals to rely on their meaning until explicitly changed."Â  Weaver
    v. Graham, 450 U.S. 24, 28-29 (1981).Â  For a law to present an ex post
      facto violation, the law must (1) be retrospective and apply to events
  taking place prior to its enactment and (2) work to disadvantage the offender. Â State
    v. Huiett, 302 S.C. 169, 171, 394 S.E.2d 486, 487 (1990).
The seminal case of Calder v. Bull, 3 U.S. 386
  (1798), sets forth four general categories of law that are violative of the ex
    post facto clause of the United States Constitution. 

  1st. Every law that makes an action, done before the
    passing of the law, and which was innocent when done, criminal; and punishes
    such action. 2nd. Every law that aggravates a crime, or makes it greater than
    it was, when committed. 3rd. Every law that changes the punishment, and
    inflicts a greater punishment, than the law annexed to the crime, when
    committed. 4th. Every law that alters the legal rules of evidence, and receives
    less, or different, testimony, than the law required at the time of the
    commission of the offence, in order to convict the offender.Â  

Id. at 390.
A
  change in the law does not run afoul of the ex post facto clause if it
  only affects a mode of procedure and does not alter "substantial personal
  rights."Â  Huiett, 302 S.C. at 171, 394 S.E.2d at 487 (quoting Miller,
  482 U.S. at 430).Â  Furthermore, in order for the ex post facto clause to
  be implicated, the statute at issue must be criminal or penal in purpose and
  nature.Â  Id. at 172, 394 S.E.2d at 487.Â  "Even though
  a procedural change may have a detrimental impact on a defendant, a mere
  procedural change which does not affect substantial rights is not ex post
    facto."Â  Id. at 171-72, 394 S.E.2d at 487. 
The
  United States Supreme Court has determined changes in laws that made previously
  inadmissible evidence admissible did not violate the ex post facto clause.Â  See Thompson v. Missouri, 171 U.S. 380, 386-87 (1898)
  (finding application of law admitting previously inadmissible handwriting
  samples did not violate ex post facto clause); Hopt v. Utah, 110
  U.S. 574, 589 (1884) (holding admission of convicted felon's testimony,
  inadmissible at the time homicide was committed, did not violate ex post
    facto clause).
Other jurisdictions that have considered the admission
  of hearsay statements of child victims have reached the same conclusion.Â  See Hall v. Vargas, 608 S.E.2d 200, 202 (Ga. 2005) (holding statutory change
  permitting state to introduce additional evidence in the form of hearsay
  statements attributed to child victim did not present an ex post facto violation); Villalon v. State, 805 S.W.2d 588, 591-92 (Tex. Ct. App.
  1991) (finding statutory amendment changing rule of evidence to eliminate
  hearsay as a bar to the admissibility of certain category of outcry statements
  did not violate the ex post facto clause); Gladening v. State,
  503 So. 2d 335, 337-38 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 1987) (finding no ex post facto violation when statutory amendment "did not increase the punishment or
  deprive [defendant] of a defense" and "the statute had no effect upon
  whether [defendant] committed the crime but simply authorized the introduction
  of additional evidence to demonstrate his guilt").
The
  admission of the previously inadmissible videotaped interviews did not change
  the quantum of evidence required to convict Bryant nor did it change the
  elements of the crime.Â  Once the jury determined Bryant's guilt, the admission
  of the videotape did not alter or effect the punishment to which he was
  subject.Â  Rather than being penal in nature, section 17-23-175 deals with
  procedural, evidentiary matters.Â  Consequently, we do not believe this addition
  to the statutory scheme allowing for such out-of-court statement falls into one
  of the four categories set forth in Calder. 
Based
  on the foregoing, we conclude the admission of the victims' videotaped
  interviews under section 17-23-175 did not violate the ex post facto clause and did not contradict the savings clause found in the Act.Â  Therefore,
  the ruling of the trial court isÂ  Â Â 
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.
